name: Australis Tabs Down Under
description: Move the tab bar below the nav-bar (aka "tabs on the bottom") and turn the tabs upside down. Also make the tab bar and nav-bar thinner.

additional_info:
<u>Future plans for this style</u>
There are several color theories to work with involving memory, psychology, and emotion. Also, many country flags are "tri-color" (so a nav-box with 3 bars works well for that--the French flag being one of the simplest to use as a pattern [just turn it on its side and you're there]). Anyway, most people like to decorate the rooms of their homes by painting the walls different colors for each room. That's how I see the potential for the menu-bookmarks-buttons layout of this style. You can get a head-start on me by playing around with different colors; you just have to edit the CSS to change a few color codes. The most basic natural color progressions can be seen in rainbows: ROYGBIV (for dark backgrounds, use white text and/or button icons). Well, lots to play with here.
----
The yellow (Menu Bar) and orange (Bookmarks) colors are pulled from the Mozilla Firefox style guide. The blue backgrounds were also pulled from Mozilla but lightened up more than a little bit. So, yes, you can color-code your toolbars--menus vs. bookmarks vs. buttons (might be useful--or just nice to look at... might not).

Most of what I did to modify the default layout involves simply using Firefox customization. First, enable the Menu Bar. Next, drag the Bookmarks Toolbar Items from the Bookmarks Toolbar to the Menu Bar (in Customize). You can then disable the Bookmarks Toolbar. After that, just drag the buttons you want there up onto the Menu Bar (or wherever). Lastly, this CSS reverses the nav-bar and the tabs. It modifies sizing and spacing, but not by a lot. It also sets some background colors, to better show where things are (easy to change or get rid of). Not much to it.
